content.description:
Work your way up the corner crack with great protection on purple rock.  
  
 There is a rap station at the top of the route which requires two rope rappel (40m). There is a secondary rap station directly below in an alcove or use the two pitons halfway though the route below roof on the route.  
  
 It is much easier to have a follower clean then try to basically downclimb to reach the slanted corner from anchors.


Located in the prominant corner between Air Voyage Wall and Amphitheater wall. Scramble behind the huge boulder to get to the base.

Trad to 3"

A cruxy rightward traverse leads to a slab, pull the roof on positive holds and continue to a second roof. Pull this and head straight up to the anchors. 



Start up towards a left-leaning diagonal to the right of Violet Hour. 

Gear to 3” FP mentioned in some descriptions is no longer present. Bolted anchor.

Climb the wide crack system to a two bolt anchor.

Wide crack system just right of Imaginary Grace.
Standard rack of nuts and cams to BD #3. You can place a #4 near the start if you brought one.

This slightly wondery climb includes lots of interesting moves and puzzles. Very good!

Route at the bottom of the mostly rotted out log stairs starting off the steep scree.
10 bolts to anchors

A high first bolt before the roof marks the start of the fun. Avoiding the arete makes for a harder, better finish. Equipped with a clip 'n go anchor.

Climbs the south-west face of the boulder that protects the belays of Air Voyage Wall.
Three bolts plus clip 'n go anchor

Follow the arête onto a slab, then up parallel cracks, pull the first roof and step right to the chains. 



Start left of the atête and traverse in on jugs, or directly up the arête (off balance). 

Gear to 4”, bolted anchor.

This sport route sits alone on the face above the talus field. Climb through interesting moves using lots of juggy horizontals.

Start from a small ledge near the top of the talus field.
9 bolts to anchors.

To the right of Imaginary Face climb the up directly below a finger crack halfway up the wall. There is room for pro within the first ten feet so place some because there is a 20 ft run out until you reach the crack. Follow the finger crack up until you reach the shale layer which you climb up and eventually right to a chain anchor.

Right of Imaginary Face and left of Election Night.
Gear to 3"

Goodness what an enjoyable pitch, great stone with fun movement and good protection.   
  
 Start at the base of the log stairs in a left facing corner.  Stemming and a small bit of jamming technique will get you to where you traverse right (below a sub anchor comprised of cord and pins) into the arching wide crack/chimney feature.  Not to worry, you stem around everything using big horizontals and hand jams.  Keep going until you reach an anchor on a nice ledge.

Right side Amphitheater, bottom of log stairs.
Singles to 3" with a fair number of runners.  Be cautious if lowering with a 60.

This appears to be a recently added sport climb between the trad lines Corner Journey and I Hear My Train A-Comin' at The Amphitheatre Wall. It does not appear in the 2017 edition of Bow Valley Sport by Derek Galloway. The Banff Rock guidebook by Chris Perry shows a 5.10a R trad route in this vicinity called Mammary Lane, so perhaps this is a retro-bolted version of that originally ill-protected line.

A few strenuous undercling moves are required to pass a minor roof at the start. This felt like the crux. Thoughtful, steep, and fun, 5.9/5.10a climbing leads to the anchor. The second to last bolt seems awkwardly placed far left of the natural line, and getting to it feels a bit dicey. A fall here would mean penduluming with your feet several feet higher than the last bolt. These moves can be protected by a bomber finger sized cam placement in a horizontal crack.

The only bolted line just left of Corner Journey.
Bolts and an optional finger sized cam (BD 0.3 X4 was perfect). Double bolt anchor at top.

Probably the least enjoyable route I've encountered at the Lake but still worth while...I guess.  It is unfortunately a fair bit contrived and the pin protecting the crux is comical and maliciously placed in the jug. 
  
 Begin by stair stepping the blocks towards the roof with the obvious cord coming out of something.  Place some gear and cut loose, execute a few awkward humping maneuvers (hoocha hoocha hoocha, lobster) on positive holds.   
  
 The rest is pretty boring and full of detritus on holds and in the cracks.  Oh well.

Left of Violet Hour, the U-shaped hueco stuffed with metal and chalk is quite obvious.
Singles to 2" with supplemental wires

Grab jugs, place in cracks 
 Start just above the log stairs, climb up atop a small pillar (fixed cam).  Work through roofs to a crack which leads to the anchors.  A devious little mantel more akin to quartzite's more alpine brethren guards the summit on this one.

Right side amphitheater, just above the log stairs.
Single rack to #3 C4.  Some runners for drag reduction

The Amphitheater has a good selection of moderate routes.   The majority tend to be trad, including several 2 pitch climbs, however there are a few sport lines too. 
  
 Unlike the majority of the other routes here this area has a selection of routes that are not on steep and overhanging rock.
